Basis

  //   Topics: Linear Algebra

A basis of a vector space \(\pmb {V}\) is a minimal spanning set for \(\pmb {V}\). In other words, it is a set of linearly independent vectors that span \(\pmb {V}\); any vector in \(\pmb {V}\) may be written as a linear combination of basis vectors.

If \(\pmb {V}\) has a basis with a finite number of elements, we call \(\pmb {V}\) finite dimensional. Furthermore, if \(\pmb {V}\) is finite dimensional, then every basis for \(\pmb {V}\) has the same cardinality, and we call that cardinality the dimension of \(\pmb {V}\).
